metadata.titleEn: Landcover dataset at Qilian Mountain area (V1.0) (2018)
metadata.description: This dataset contains land cover products in Qilian Mountain Area in 2018. The dataset was produced by two steps. Firstly, land cover product in 2015 is produced using time series Landsat-8/OLI data. In view of the different NDVI time series curves of various land features with time variation, the knowledge of different land features is summarized, the extraction rules of different land features are set, and the land cover classification map in 2015 is obtained. The classification system refers to IGBP and FROM_LC classification system. It is divided into 10 categories: cultivated land, woodland, grassland, shrub, wetland, water body, impermeable surface, bare land, glacier and snow cover. According to the accuracy evaluation of Google Earth high-definition image and field survey data, the overall accuracy of land cover classification products in 2015 is as high as 92.19%. Secondly, taking the land cover classification products in 2015 as the base map, a large number of samples are selected according to the proportion of different types. Based on the Landsat series data and powerful data processing ability of Google Earth Engine platform, the random forest classifier is selected to train the band information and NDVI, MNDWI, NDBI and other indices by using the idea of in-depth learning. The land cover of 2018 is produced. It is concluded that the land cover classified products based on Google Earth Engine platform have good consistency with those based on time series method. In conclusion, the land cover data set in the core area of Qilian Mountains has high overall accuracy, and the method based on sample training of Google Earth Engine platform can expand the existing classification products in time and space, and the frequency of every five years can reflect more land cover type change information in long time series.

background: The increased information on time dimension of time series HJ-1/CCD data improves the classification accuracy for most of the land cover types including water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands; consequently, the overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient have 10% and 0.1 improvements respectively. The advantage of HJ-1/CCD data in land cover/use classification makes it a reference for new remote sensing satellite or sensor development. Overall, a new land cover/use classification method using HJ-1/CCD data based on time series analysis is developed and this method does improve the classification accuracy compared with the method using single remote sensing data. In addition, the introducing of the very high spatial resolution data within Google Earth can also improve the sampling accuracy and lower the cost of data purchasing and field campaigns.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the spatiotemporal advantage of HJ-1/CCD data we propose a new method for finer resolution land cover mapping using time series HJ-1/CCD data, which can greatly improve the land cover mapping accuracy.
challenges: This method uses much more data and dramatically increases the computation loading; the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use.
methods: In this study, the advantages of HJ-1/CCD on spatial resolution and temporal frequency are fully taken to make a time series data with 30 m spatial resolution of experimental areas. The land cover classification method using time series HJ-1/CCD data includes six steps, which are detailed as follows: (1) Constructing the time series HJ-1/CCD data. In order to take advantages of HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping, the composite of experimental areas is made using multi-scenes of HJ-1/CCD images, and 12 composites corresponding to 12 months in 2010 are made, which are made up the time series images of the experimental areas yearly. (2) Data preprocessing. After the data are prepared, the data pre-processes including geometric correction, radiometric calibration and atmospheric correction need to be done to make a “perfect” time series HJ-1/CCD data composite. (3) NDVI calculating. Instead of time series of HJ-1/CCD data, time series of NDVI are used as the input of SVM for classification. (1) Sampling. The classifier used in this study is SVM, which needs a good sample set for training purpose. (2) SVM classification. Support Vector Machine (SVM) is a robotic learning method developed from statistics learning theory and optimization theory in the 1990s. (3) Post-classification. Some of the land cover types are very difficult to separate, so some extra work needs to be done to improve the classification accuracy.
dataset: The data are downloaded for free at websites of Satellite Environment Center, Ministry of Environmental Protection or China Center of Resources Satellite Data and Application. The HJ-1 satellite constellation consists of three satellites, named as HJ-1A, HJ-1B, and HJ-1C respectively. HJ-1A has two CCD cameras and one hyperspectral instrument onboard; HJ-1B has two CCD cameras and one infrared camera onboard; HJ-1C is a SAR satellite. For CCD cameras, their nominal spatial resolution is 30 m. HJ-1/CCDs have three visible bands (430–520 nm, 520–600 nm, and 630–690 nm) and one near-infrared band (760–900 nm).
findings: In our two study areas, the very high resolution remote sensing data within Google Earth are used to validate the land cover mapping results, which shows a very high mapping accuracy of 95.76% and 83.78% and a high Kappa coefficient of 0.9423 and 0.8165 in the Dahuofang area of Liaoning Province and the Heiquan area of Gansu Province respectively.

background: Land-cover datasets are crucial for research on eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling. Remote sensing has become widely used as a macro-observing system for land-cover mapping, which can substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as the baseline. Several moderate to fine resolution global land-cover datasets, which are presented in detail in Table I, based on different satellite sensors are available from different research groups. These land-cover datasets listed in Table I have large variability for three reasons: 1) the data quality and properties are different; 2) there is no standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories; and 3) they are not consistent with the Earth System Model’s (ESM) requirements, because the concept of PFT, whose traits represent a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions, used in ESMs cannot be mapped directly using remote-sensing land-cover datasets. The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.
research objective: In order to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the HRB, a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation is developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.
challenges: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.
methods: The procedure for constructing time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD is introduced as follows and the details of the procedure can be found in [26]. Geometric correction: A mosaic of the HRB is made using Landsat/TM imagery. The mosaic of Landsat/TM is used as the base image and all HJ-1/CCD images are automatically corrected through the image-to-image registration method by [43]. Radiometric calibration: Converting the DN values of the HJ-1/CCD images to top of atmosphere (TOA) radiance with given calibration coefficients. Atmospheric correction: Removing the atmospheric effects of remote-sensing images to obtain the surface reflectance. This correction was achieved with a spatial extension method developed by [44]. After the preprocessing has been done, all the HJ-1/CCD images within 1 month are subset and mosaicked; consequently, 10 mosaics for 10 months in the HRB are made and time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD are constructed.
dataset: The HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data used in this research were provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application (CRESDA, http://www.cresda.com). The Landsat TM/ETM+ data were downloaded from the USGS website (http://landsat.usgs.gov/). The MODIS data were downloaded from the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (http://ladsweb.nascom.nasa.gov/). The VHSR data were from Google Earth by Google Inc.
findings: A ground campaign was performed to evaluate the accuracy of crop classification and an overall accuracy of 84.09% for the crop classification was achieved.

Definition.Question: What is the role of NDVI time series in land cover classification and how is it utilized?
Definition.Answer: NDVI time series plays a crucial role in land cover classification by providing data on the temporal variation of vegetation. It is utilized by analyzing the different NDVI time series curves for various land cover types, which helps in distinguishing between different features and setting extraction rules for land cover classification.

Definition.Question: What are the typical challenges faced in land cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery?
Definition.Answer: Typical challenges in land cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery include high uncertainty in differentiating categories such as cropland and grassland, as well as shrub, grassland, and forest in dryland systems, mainly due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.

Definition.Question: How does the integration of multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data improve land cover mapping accuracy?
Definition.Answer: The integration of multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data improves land cover mapping accuracy by providing a comprehensive approach that utilizes different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands, allowing for a more detailed and accurate classification of land cover types.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification compare to the challenges of using other remote sensing datasets like MODIS or Landsat?
Comparison.Answer: HJ-1/CCD data presents challenges such as increased computation load and issues with geometric and radiometric quality, whereas using datasets like MODIS or Landsat can face challenges related to variability in data quality, classification standards, and consistency with Earth System Models. HJ-1/CCD's spatial and temporal resolution offers advantages, but its usability is hindered by data quality issues.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of time series data, such as from Landsat-8/OLI, improve the accuracy of land cover classification in remote sensing?
Interpretation.Answer: Time series data, like those from Landsat-8/OLI, provide detailed insights into the temporal variations of NDVI curves for different land cover types. By analyzing these variations, researchers can inductively derive rules for extracting specific land cover information, thus enhancing classification accuracy. This approach allows for a more nuanced understanding of the temporal dynamics of different land features, leading to more accurate land cover maps.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be used to ensure the high accuracy of land cover classifications when utilizing remote sensing datasets with different spatial resolutions and spectral bands?
Interpretation.Answer: To ensure high accuracy in land cover classifications using datasets with varying resolutions and spectral bands, methodologies can involve constructing time series mosaics, performing geometric and radiometric corrections, and applying atmospheric corrections. Classifiers like SVM (Support Vector Machine) can be trained with a robust sample set, and very high resolution data from platforms like Google Earth can be used for validation. These steps collectively enhance classification precision by addressing spatial and spectral discrepancies across datasets.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be challenges related to the geometric and radiometric qualities of remote sensing data when used for land cover classification?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges related to the geometric and radiometric qualities of remote sensing data, such as those from HJ-1/CCD, arise because these qualities can lower the usability of the data and increase the difficulty in its application. These challenges necessitate extensive data preprocessing steps, such as geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction, to ensure that the data is suitable for accurate land cover classification.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping compared to single remote sensing data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping can improve classification accuracy for most land cover types, including water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands. This method, although more data-intensive and computationally demanding, significantly enhances overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient by 10% and 0.1, respectively.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does incorporating very high spatial resolution data from Google Earth affect the accuracy and cost of land cover sampling and classification?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating very high spatial resolution data from Google Earth can improve the sampling accuracy and reduce the cost of data purchasing and field campaigns, resulting in a higher mapping accuracy as demonstrated in study areas where accuracy reached up to 95.76%.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of utilizing time series data and deep learning methods in land cover classification for the Qilian Mountain region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to enhance the accuracy and expand the temporal and spatial coverage of land cover classification products, reflecting more detailed changes in land cover types over time. This is achieved by using time series data from Landsat and deep learning methods, such as random forest classifiers, on platforms like Google Earth Engine.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives drive the development of a comprehensive method for mapping land cover with fine spatial resolution in eco-hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling by utilizing multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data. This method addresses the variability in data quality and classification approaches, ultimately providing more accurate and detailed land cover datasets for modeling purposes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in constructing a time series dataset using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves several steps: first, constructing the time series HJ-1/CCD data by creating composites from multi-scenes of HJ-1/CCD images for each month. This is followed by data preprocessing steps including geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction to create a 'perfect' time series HJ-1/CCD data composite. NDVI is then calculated from this time series and used as input for the SVM classifier. The final step involves post-classification to improve the classification accuracy for certain land cover types.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the spatial resolution and temporal frequency advantages of HJ-1/CCD data be leveraged for improving land cover mapping accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: HJ-1/CCD data's spatial resolution and temporal frequency are utilized by constructing a detailed time series dataset with 30 m spatial resolution for experimental areas. This involves creating monthly composites, performing data preprocessing, and using NDVI time series for classification with SVM. This method enhances land cover mapping accuracy over using single remote sensing data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approach is used to evaluate the accuracy of land cover classification using high-resolution remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The accuracy evaluation method involves using very high-resolution remote sensing data from platforms like Google Earth to validate land cover mapping results. This approach showed high mapping accuracy and a high Kappa coefficient in different study areas, indicating its effectiveness in assessing classification accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the high accuracy of land cover classification in the Qilian Mountains region using remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: The high accuracy of land cover classification is enabled by utilizing a combination of time series data from Landsat-8/OLI, deep learning techniques with random forest classifiers, and indices such as NDVI, MNDWI, and NDBI. The process involves knowledge induction of different land features over time, and validation against high-resolution Google Earth imagery and field survey data.

Enablement.Question: What factors contribute to the successful application of time series HJ-1/CCD data in improving land cover classification accuracy?
Enablement.Answer: Successful application of time series HJ-1/CCD data is attributed to its high temporal frequency and spatial resolution, which allows for improved classification accuracy. The data undergoes preprocessing steps including geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. The use of NDVI time series as input for SVM classification and validation with high-resolution remote sensing data from Google Earth also contribute to its effectiveness.

Expectation.Question: Why might the introduction of very high spatial resolution data within platforms like Google Earth improve the sampling accuracy and lower the cost of data purchasing and field campaigns in land cover classification?
Expectation.Answer: The introduction of very high spatial resolution data within platforms like Google Earth can improve sampling accuracy because it allows for more precise validation of land cover mapping results. High resolution data provides detailed imagery that can facilitate better identification and differentiation of land cover types, reducing uncertainty and errors. Additionally, access to such data can eliminate the need for extensive field campaigns, thus lowering costs associated with data collection.

Expectation.Question: Why is there often high uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery, particularly between categories like cropland and grassland or among shrub, grassland, and forest in dryland systems?
Expectation.Answer: High uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery is often due to the inherent variability and overlap in spectral signatures of different land cover types. In dryland systems, the distinction between categories like shrub, grassland, and forest is particularly challenging because of the subtle differences in vegetation density and cover. Additionally, the minimum threshold required for forest cover can vary, leading to inconsistencies and misclassification.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges of using time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification, particularly in terms of computational load and data quality?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification presents significant challenges, primarily due to the increased data volume and resulting computational demands. Additionally, the mediocre geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data can hinder usability and complicate the classification process, affecting the overall accuracy of the method despite its potential advantages in spatial resolution and temporal frequency.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways do you think integrating multiple remote sensing data sources could improve land cover classification accuracy, especially in eco-hydrological modeling?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating multiple remote sensing data sources, such as HJ-1/CCD, Landsat TM/ETM+, MODIS, and very high spatial resolution data from Google Earth, can enhance land cover classification accuracy by leveraging their different spatial resolutions and spectral bands. This comprehensive approach allows for finer spatial resolution mapping and more detailed classification categories, thereby addressing uncertainties in specific land cover types and improving the reliability of eco-hydrological and land-process models.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how data from multiple satellite sensors can be integrated to improve land-cover classification accuracy.
Assertion.Answer: The integration of data from multiple satellite sensors, such as HJ-1/CCD and Landsat, allows for a comprehensive approach by utilizing different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands. This improves the classification accuracy by addressing the variations in data quality and properties, and by using time series data to better capture the dynamics of land-cover changes.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the challenges associated with using optical remotely sensed imagery for land-cover classification, especially between similar categories.
Assertion.Answer: The main challenge with optical remotely sensed imagery is the high uncertainty in distinguishing between similar land-cover categories like cropland and grassland or among shrub, grassland, and forest in dryland systems. This is due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover and the lack of a standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a data collection method that enhances land cover classification accuracy using time series satellite data.
Request/Directive.Answer: A method to improve land cover classification accuracy involves constructing time series data using HJ-1/CCD satellite imagery. This process includes creating composites from multiple HJ-1/CCD images corresponding to different months, performing geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction to prepare a precise time series data set. Using these time series, indices like NDVI are calculated and used as inputs for classification with algorithms such as SVM, improving the classification accuracy significantly.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify challenges associated with using optical remote sensing data for land cover classification, particularly in differentiating between specific vegetation categories.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the main challenges in using optical remote sensing data for land cover classification is the high uncertainty in differentiating between categories like cropland, grassland, and forest, especially in dryland systems. This challenge arises due to the variable minimum threshold required for forest cover, leading to difficulties in accurately classifying these overlapping vegetation types.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline potential datasets available for land cover classification that incorporate multi-spectral and multi-temporal data sources.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for land cover classification include HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application, Landsat TM/ETM+ data from the USGS, and MODIS data from NASA. These datasets offer multi-spectral and multi-temporal coverage, allowing for comprehensive land cover mapping when combined with data from very high spatial resolution sources like Google Earth.
